meeting_annotations.speaker: Jennifer Wilcox
meeting_annotations.transcript: One thing I'll echo too is I I recognize that a lot of what everybody's trying to do is thinking about fundamental research and advancing that. So like in the United States today, if we do a lot of separation of CO2 and we deploy it and we get it at scale, one of the one of the barriers is that we don't have the infrastructure to move the CO2 around. Like site to site it it's it's pretty well known that if you're moving around on the order of 700,000 tons of CO2 from a site that that pipeline infrastructure is cheaper than trucking it. You know, about that about that scale. And so we just don't have a lot of infrastructure for moving CO2 around in the US. And if we're thinking about capture and utilization, that is an opportunity so that we don't have to build all of that pipe pipeline network. But if you're converting it to something like methanol, you know, something that can be easily moved and we know how to do it pretty pretty well, you do have to ask the questions where where does the hydrogen come from?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jennifer Wilcox
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh there are actually I I can have a a great answer here. There are actually two routes you can get hydrogen. One is uh for example if you're doing the CO2 hydrogenation using thermal catalysis, the hydrogen nowadays majority of them coming from uh uh methane reforming, right? Uh that still give you give you you consume the fossil fuel, you produce CO2. But there is also uh the technology uh uh we have been, you know, exploring for a long time that is using electricity for water splitting. Uh now select the the the not select the the efficiency can be very high actually to up to 80% converting electricity to hydrogen to hydrogen. Uh and with the price of the electricity coming down uh, you know, in the future, it can be more attractive. That's one route. Another route is um directly electrifying carbon dioxide into the liquid fuels or other type of fuels. That doesn't involve molecular hydrogen but they still use the protons that is coming from water, you're dumping electrons uh using electrocatalysis into carbon dioxide coupling with the protons from water, you can also directly generate uh you know, formic acid, methanol, ethanol and so on. There is also a field that is uh we are working on uh in terms of uh not directly mixing CO2 with molecular hydrogen and cap like that.
